monthly_spend_analysis_data.ai_summary: Your total income for January was $2,345.67, primarily from retirement or pension. Your major expenses were groceries ($200.75, 8.6% of income), medical ($195, 8.3%), entertainment ($35.99, 1.5%), transportation ($65.3, 2.8%), and personal care ($45, 1.9%). Your total spending was $542.04, around 23.1% of your income. To better manage your finances and achieve your goal of paying off student loans, consider reducing discretionary spending on entertainment and personal care. Additionally, explore options to lower medical expenses, such as insurance plans or negotiating costs.

Your total income for February was $2,345.67, primarily from a retirement or pension payment. Your major expenses were groceries ($181.77, 7.7% of income), restaurants ($75.50, 3.2%), general merchandise ($129.99, 5.5%), transportation ($65.00, 2.8%), and medical expenses ($165.99, 7.1%). Your total spending was $618.25, accounting for 26.3% of your income. To better manage your finances and achieve your goal of paying off student loans, consider reducing discretionary spending on dining out and shopping. Additionally, explore options to lower medical and utility costs. Consistently monitoring your expenses and sticking to a budget can help you allocate more funds towards debt repayment.

Your total income for March was $2,345.67, primarily from retirement/pension. Your major expenses were groceries ($140.57, 6.0%), utilities ($270.0, 11.5%), medical ($134.99, 5.8%), and entertainment ($25.0, 1.1%). Your total spending was $601.06 (25.6% of income). To achieve your goal of paying off student loans, consider reducing discretionary spending on dining out and entertainment. Explore balance transfer credit cards with 0% APR to consolidate high-interest debt.

Your total income for April was $2,345.67, primarily from retirement or pension. Your major expenses were groceries ($125.89), dining out ($65.32), utilities ($205.67), and transportation ($42.15). While entertainment spending was low at $25, you could optimize your budget by cooking more at home and reducing dining out. Consider setting a monthly grocery and dining budget. Overall, you spent around 20% of your income, leaving room for savings towards your goal of paying off student loans.
